The State says, a fair shot.
A fair shot is code for proportionality, because proportionality is all they argued at the district court.
They read De Grandy as sanctioning proportionality, and I read--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why isn't it a compelling... isn't it--

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: --that opinion very differently.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Couldn't it be a compelling interest that in a particular place for many, many years... many, many, many, many yeas the State was set up in such a way to prevent African Americans from having the same kind of vote, or even having a vote, as other persons had?
I mean, wouldn't that be a justification, possibly, in particular circumstances for overcoming the effects of a history of discrimination?

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: Yes, that would become... but then we would go into traditional equal protection analysis.
Have you, the State of Georgia, come up with a limited race-based remedy, temporary in nature, and narrowly tailored to the purpose.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So then, would we then use--

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: It can't just automatically be proportionality.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --But then would we then use, if we got past the threshold and then we found such a compelling interest, then would you not use what the Abrams briefs or some of the briefs have, the five, the traditional tests that this Court's developed in order to show narrow tailoring that... limited in duration... you know the five.

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Limited in duration, it's roughly--

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --equivalent to the--

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: Right.
But we get to the point, they're not contending that.
They are contending that proportionality in and of itself is a State sovereign legislative prerogative that they don't... that they... they're asking this Court to politely butt out.

They're saying to the courts of the United States that we want, under some States' rights theory, the right, even though we really did this because the Justice Department made us do it, we have to defend it, and what we want to say is, is that if we want to manipulate racially our political boundaries, it's no business of the Federal Government.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Well, you would agree, would you not, that if the city, say, was composed of one-third Polish Americans, one-third Swedish Americans, and one-third Irish Americans, they could set out to divide up the city council in thirds for representation of each.
That would be constitutionally permissible, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: If that is the only--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's the only reason, yes.

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: --I would hope not, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You'd hope they wouldn't do it, but would it be--

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: No, I hope that would not be constitutional.
That was the only expressed reason... no communities of interest, no nothing.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Other than a presumption that may or may not be valid--

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --that Swedish Americans tend to share certain interests, they have Swedish clubs and--

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: And that's why strict scrutiny helps us with this.
It makes--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But you'd say strict scrutiny would be required even though there was no racial basis in that one?

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: --Shaw says racial or ethnic enclaves.
Are these not ethnic enclaves, and is an ethnic enclave somehow more constitutional than a racial enclave?
We read... we don't read a distinction in the Shaw case.
If you are separating people because of their race, and ethnicity is certainly a subcategory of race, I want the State to have to go through the hoops.

It may well get through it, because it will show that when we go into Chinatown, the signs are all in Chinese, and everyone worships a different God, and these people have genuine, independent community-based needs to have a political voice that is weighted in a plethora of other interests, rather than--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Parks.

turn.speaker: a_lee_parks
turn.label: Mr. A. Lee Parks
turn.text: --Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until Monday at 10 o'clock.
